A team of MIT researchers has found, for the first time, exactly how different molecular components work together to block the flow of blood from a cut. Now, they are working on applying that knowledge to the development of synthetic materials that could be used to control different kinds of liquid flows, and could lead to a variety of new self-assembling materials. http://mitne.ws/TJqHqB Timeline Photos
MIT researchers are designing tools to analyze cells at the microscale, which could lead to big medical discoveries. http://mitne.ws/ZlLMX4 Timeline Photos

A coated surface with nanostructured patterns that was recently designed, built and tested by MIT researchers could make for more efficient power generation and desalination. http://mitne.ws/TNu26I Timeline Photos

Researchers at MIT, the Broad Institute and Rockefeller University have developed a new technique for precisely altering the genomes of living cells by adding or deleting genes. The researchers say the technology could lead to new therapies, among other potential applications. http://mitne.ws/UJ9Fsp Timeline Photos
MIT researchers built some pretty amazing little machines in 2012. Check them out: http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear Timeline Photos

This year, MIT researchers engineered a device that delivers a tiny, high-pressure jet of medicine through the skin without the use of a hypodermic needle. The device can be programmed to deliver a range of doses to various depths — an improvement over similar jet-injection systems that are now commercially available. http://mitne.ws/bestoftheyear Timeline Photos
A new spectroscopy technique developed at MIT and Case Western Reserve University could help doctors better identify breast tumors. http://mitne.ws/TZqLAV Timeline Photos
As the holiday shopping season winds down, we just have to ask: If you could have any of these not-yet-to-market innovations from MIT, which would you want?

MIT researchers have uncovered a fundamentally new kind of magnetic behavior, which could possibly lead to advances in data storage or communications. http://mitne.ws/UErJ4S MIT researchers discover a new kind of magnetism - MIT News Office Experiments demonstrate ‘quantum spin liquid,’ which could have applications in new computer memory storage.

A possible path to earlier cancer detection: Researchers at MIT have developed nanoparticles that can home to a tumor and interact with cancer proteins to produce thousands of biomarkers, which can then be easily detected in a patient’s urine. http://mitne.ws/SGfIzF Timeline Photos

Find out how porcupines could help engineers design better medical devices. http://mitne.ws/S4QTwZ 

(Photo: Mike Cuccarese) Timeline Photos
Do you have a consistent approach to your financial choices? A new study shows that at most a third of us do. Find out more: http://mitne.ws/RwIQJk Timeline Photos

A new approach that allows objects to become “invisible” has now been applied to an entirely different area: letting particles “hide” from passing electrons, which could lead to more efficient thermoelectric devices and new kinds of electronics. ‘Invisibility’ could be a key to better electronics - MIT News Office MIT team applies technology developed for visual ‘cloaking’ to enable more efficient transfer of electrons.

Are you up in our neck of the woods, leaf peeping this weekend? If so, you'd be surprised how much carbon dioxide those beautiful leaves carry with them. The mathematics of leaf decay - MIT News Office A mathematical model reveals commonality within the diversity of leaf decay.

Diving into a pool from a few feet up allows you to enter the water smoothly and painlessly, but jumping from a bridge can lead to a fatal impact. The water is the same in each case, so why is the effect of hitting its surface so different? Probing the mysteries of cracks and stresses - MIT News Office Analysis of molecular-level fracture and stress mechanisms could have broad implications for understanding materials’ behavior.

“We’re hoping that some of the information we’ve been able to glean from our study will help us to approach a new understanding of heart development, and also lead to the possibility of using cells that are generated in a dish to replace heart cells that are lost as a consequence of aging and disease,” says Laurie Boyer, an associate professor in the MIT Department of Biology. Probing matters of the heart - MIT News Office New study of stem cell differentiation could help researchers better understand the genetic basis of heart disease.
Using ultrasound waves, researchers from MIT Chemical Engineering (ChemE) boost skin’s permeability to drugs. Getting (drugs) under your skin - MIT News Office

NASA, MIT's Lincoln Laboratory and others have opened up a contest (for those 18 and younger) to name an asteroid. So, what would you name it? 

Learn more about the contest at http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/nasa-announces-asteroid-naming-contest-for-students-0905.html Timeline Photos

“What it does is take whatever carbon is available, and stores it in the form of a polymer, which is similar in its properties to a lot of petroleum-based plastics,” Brigham says. By knocking out a few genes, inserting a gene from another organism and tinkering with the expression of other genes, Brigham and his colleagues were able to redirect the microbe to make fuel instead of plastic. Teaching a microbe to make fuel - MIT News Office Genetically modified organism could turn carbon dioxide or waste products into a gasoline-compatible transportation fuel.

A team of researchers from the MIT Department of Physics and Harvard University has achieved a crucial long-term goal of efforts to create quantum devices: the ability to convert a laser beam into a stream of single photons, or particles of light, in a controlled way. Single-photon transmitter could enable new quantum devices - MIT News Office Long-sought goal for quantum devices — the ability to transmit single photons while blocking multiple photons — is finally achieved.

MIT chemistry professor Stephen J. Lippard, who has spent much of his career studying platinum drugs, has now identified a compound that kills cancer cells better than cisplatin, the most commonly used platinum anticancer drug. The new compound may be able to evade cancer-cell resistance to conventional platinum compounds. New drug candidate shows promise against cancer - MIT News Office Platinum compound may offer an alternative to cisplatin, a widely used chemotherapy agent.

In clinical trial, a cocktail of three naturally occurring dietary compounds shows success in restoring memory in patients with early Alzheimer's. Nutrient mixture improves memory in patients with early Alzheimer’s - MIT News Office In clinical trial, mixture developed at MIT appears to help overcome loss of connections between brain cells.

Researchers led by an MIT postdoc have analyzed an artificial system that models the light-capturing method used by deep-sea bacteria. Researchers explain how dye-based nanotubes can help harvest light’s energy - MIT News Office Tiny cylinders help reveal how natural-light-harvesting antennae collect light with exceptional efficiency.

“Water is not most usefully thought of as a scarce resource,” says Larry Susskind. “It’s a flexible resource. It’s not that there’s not enough water. It’s that we waste it and don’t invest in the technologies that would allow us to make more efficient uses of it. Book details a new model for sharing water - MIT News Office Sure, water is in great demand — but that doesn’t mean supply is a zero-sum game among neighboring countries, an MIT professor says in a new book.

The key to the new process is very precise control over the size of the holes in the graphene sheet. “There’s a sweet spot, but it’s very small,” says Jeffrey Grossman — between pores so large that salt could pass through and ones so small that water molecules would be blocked. A new approach to water desalination - MIT News Office Graphene sheets with precisely controlled pores have potential to purify water more efficiently than existing methods.

“Random-matrix theory allows us to understand how disorder in a material affects its electrical properties" - Jiahao Chen, MIT Chemistry Department  New technique allows simulation of noncrystalline materials Multidisciplinary team develops mathematical approach that could help in simulating materials for solar cells and LEDs.
Harnessing heat radiation that most solar cells ignore All-carbon solar cell harnesses infrared light

In under two minutes, learn how these polymers may change the future of microchips.  Tinier Wires [Video] Researchers at MIT have found a new way of making complex three-dimensional structures using self-assembling polymer materials that form tiny wires and junctions.

“The field of ultrasound is still developing. Ultrasound will partially replace CT scans, reduce radiation exposure to patients and make diagnosing easier when away from the high-cost hospitals. It can help our world provide care at a more reasonable cost with a new paradigm of care.” Sharper ultrasound images could improve diagnostics - MIT News Office New system developed at MIT allows precise measurements and tracking of disease progression.

"The secret lies in a pattern of tiny inverted pyramids etched into the surface of the silicon. These tiny indentations, each less than a millionth of a meter across, can trap rays of light as effectively as conventional solid silicon surfaces that are 30 times thicker." Textured surface may boost power output of thin silicon solar cells MIT team finds new approach to trapping  light efficiently in thin-film silicon solar cells.

The researchers, led by Rahul Sarpeshkar, an associate professor of MIT EECS Department, fabricated the fuel cell on a silicon chip. New energy source for future medical implants: sugar - MIT News Office Implantable fuel cell built at MIT could power neural prosthetics that help patients regain control of limbs.

Using a technique known as “nucleic acid origami,” chemical engineers have built tiny particles made out of DNA and RNA that can deliver snippets of RNA directly to tumors, turning off genes expressed in cancer cells. Researchers achieve RNA interference, in a lighter package - MIT News Office Pared-down nucleic acid nanoparticle poses less risk of side effects, offers better targeting.

Using stiffer pavements on the nation’s roads could reduce vehicle fuel consumption by as much as 3 percent — a savings that could add up to 273 million barrels of crude oil per year, or $15.6 billion at today’s oil prices. This would result in an accompanying annual decrease in CO2 emissions of 46.5 million metric tons.  Civil engineers find savings where the rubber meets the road - MIT News Office Study shows that pavement deflection under vehicle tires makes for a continuous uphill drive that increases fuel consumption.

In a new paper, published in Cell today, the researchers showed that staggering the doses of two specific drugs dramatically boosts their ability to kill a particularly malignant type of breast cancer cells. One-two punch knocks out aggressive breast cancer cells - MIT News Office New MIT study shows that staggered delivery of cancer drugs is far more effective than administering them at the same time.

Every year, more than a million Americans receive an artificial hip or knee prosthesis. Such implants are designed to last many years, but in about 17 percent of patients who receive a total joint replacement, the implant eventually loosens and has to be replaced early, which can cause dangerous complications for elderly patients.

To help minimize these burdensome operations, a team of MIT chemical engineers has developed a new coating for implants that could help them better adhere to the patient’s bone, preventing premature failure.  New coating for hip implants could prevent premature failure - MIT News Office Nanoscale films developed at MIT promote bone growth, creating a stronger seal between implants and patients’ own bone.

“You normally have to put a lot of energy into converting carbon dioxide into something useful,” says Kimberly Hamad-Schifferli, an associate professor of mechanical engineering and biological engineering. “We demonstrated hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles are much more stable, and have the potential to lower the energy you need for the reaction.”  Hybrid copper-gold nanoparticles convert CO2 May reduce greenhouse gas emissions

As the world moves toward greater use of low-carbon and zero-carbon energy sources, a possible bottleneck looms, according to a new MIT study: the supply of certain metals (rare earth metals) needed for key clean-energy technologies. Clean energy could lead to scarce materials - MIT News Office Rising demand for wind turbines and electric vehicles could strain supplies of some rare earth metals.

A team of MIT researchers has developed a new type of nanoparticle that can synthesize proteins on demand. Once these “protein-factory” particles reach their targets, the researchers can turn on protein synthesis by shining ultraviolet light on them — effectively creating cancer drugs at the site of the tumor. Nano-sized ‘factories’ churn out proteins - MIT News Office Tiny particles could manufacture cancer drugs at tumor sites.

Miles' work includes work on printable, flexible solar cells that can be added to paper or fabric. Read more about that work here: http://mitne.ws/w7kErY MIT student inventor Miles C. Barr receives Lemelson-MIT Student Prize - MIT News Office $30,000 Lemelson-MIT Collegiate Student Prizes awarded to inventive students at three leading universities.

To keep energy consumption under control, future chips may need to move data using light instead of electricity — and the technical expertise to build them may reside in the United States. Microchips’ optical future - MIT News Office To keep energy consumption under control, future chips may need to move data using light instead of electricity — and the technical expertise to build them may reside in the United States.

Free of charge, the I2E website has been online since July, and users have already carried out approximately 2,000 simulations. New tool for analyzing solar-cell materials - MIT News Office Website offers a way of optimizing solar cell materials and production.

“When you start to explain how difficult it would be to find the connectome of an entire brain, people ask, ‘What’s the point? That seems too far off.’ But even finding or mapping the connections in a small piece of brain can tell you a lot." My connectome, myself - MIT News Office Neuroscientist Sebastian Seung is on a quest to map brain connections that reveal how our memories and personalities take root.

“You can use anything green, even grass clippings” as the raw material, Mershin says. Harnessing nature’s solar cells - MIT News Office Photovoltaic panels made from plant material could become a cheap, easy alternative to traditional solar cells.

Jeffrey Grossman explores the materials that will make the future; as for his past: competitive ballroom dancing played a big part. “When you go dancing and look around, everyone is smiling. No one dances and is not having fun." Solving energy problems, one molecule at a time - MIT News Office Materials scientist explores new possibilities in topics from molecules to rooftop solar panels.

#MIThistory: Why is there a "J" sign on MIT Building 44? In 1974, MIT Professor Samuel C. C. Ting discovered a new kind of heavy elementary particle. Since the last meson was named the K particle, Ting named the new one the J particle. Ting won the 1976 Nobel Prize for this discovery, and gave his acceptance speech in Chinese, the first Nobel laureate to do so.

Learn more: http://mitsha.re/jparticle

In an article for POLITICO, Professor Sanjay Sarma calls attention to the security of the Internet of Things, writing, “if leaders don’t think this through, and don’t create a framework for it to succeed, there’s a real chance that the full potential of the Internet of Things could be compromised.” Read more: http://mitne.ws/1Hxtqy7 I helped invent the Internet of Things. Here’s why I’m worried about how secure it is. I'm a mechanical engineering professor at MIT, and 17 years ago, with my colleagues David Brock, Kevin Ashton and Sunny Siu, I helped launch the research effort that laid some of the groundwork for the Internet of Things. As you might imagine, my life is pretty connected.

What will an MIT education of the future look like? It is likely to be more global in its orientation and engagement, more flexible in its offerings, and more open to experiments with new modes of learning. Those are some themes of the the final report, released today, of the Institute-Wide Task Force on the Future of MIT Education, convened 18 months ago by President L. Rafael Reif to envision the MIT of 2020 and beyond. The report's release “marks the beginning of an exciting new period of educational experimentation at MIT,” Reif said. The future of MIT education looks more global, modular, and flexible Final report of Institute-wide Task Force offers 16 recommendations to help MIT evolve for a new world.

Fun facts about LEGO MIT, as seen in the Legoland Discovery Center in Somerville, MA:

-It contains more than 20,000 LEGO pieces and over 30 LED lights.

-The dome structure, a model of Building 10, is hollow but strong.

-It is part of the largest indoor LEGO "Miniland" in the world, with Boston/Cambridge landmarks made with some 1.8 million bricks and 3,000+ minifigures. 

-Tyler Holmes, assistant to the center's master LEGO builder, says the MIT model was "probably the most difficult of all the buildings in the Boston scene because of the dome."

Researchers in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences have observed a star beating for its eccentric planet. #ScienceValentines 💓 The heart of a far-off star beats for its planet Scientists observe first planet-induced stellar pulsations.

Research from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences found that certain greenhouse gases can cause sea levels to rise for hundreds of years after the pollutants have been cleared from the atmosphere. Short-lived greenhouse gases cause centuries of sea-level rise Through warming effects, methane and other gases impact rising seas long after leaving the atmosphere.

A team led by MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences; NASA; and Université de Liège (ULg) scientists has discovered that two potentially habitable planets in nearby system are rocky. Learn more: http://mitsha.re/80G6302te3E

Researchers from MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences , Princeton University, and elsewhere have developed a new technique to monitor the seasonal changes in Greenland’s ice sheet. Tracking Greenland’s ice melt with seismic waves Technique uses vibrations generated by ocean waves to monitor ice sheet’s seasonal changes.

Is there life beyond the solar system? Three exoplanets co-discovered by scientists in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences are raising new hopes of finding out. Scientists discover potentially habitable planets Just 40 light years from Earth, planets are best targets so far for search for extraterrestrial life.

Meet Colette Heald, associate professor in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences and MIT Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering who studies how particles affect air quality and climate. #womeninSTEM Colette Heald: There’s something in the air Chemist studies atmospheric gases and particles, and how they affect air quality and climate.

Good news! A study from the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences finds that our planet's geomagnetic field won't be flipping anytime soon. “We really owe microbes a lot, because there would be no complex life on Earth without these bugs.” –Tanja Bosak, scientist in the MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences Microbe sleuth Tanja Bosak examines how life and the Earth evolved in tandem during their early history together.

MIT Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences researchers are using stalagmites to learn how the American West dried out. Stalagmites pinpoint drying of American West Research suggests western U.S. deserts were relatively wet up until 8,200 years ago.

“The process may seem simple,” says Shahriar Khushrushahi, a postdoc in MIT’s Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, “but it is, inherently, supposed to be simple.” How to clean up oil spills - MIT News Office MIT researchers devise a surprisingly simple but effective method for magnetically separating oil and water.
Meet just a few of the members from this year's freshman class. Get to know the Class of 2016 - MIT News Office MIT’s freshman class represents 54 nations and is 46 percent female.

How MIT researchers might make your experience on Amazon, Orbitz, Facebook or other websites faster. Making Web applications more efficient - MIT News Office A new system that automatically streamlines database access patterns can make large Web applications up to three times as fast.

“I have been working tirelessly to make our approaches scale to the complexity of a full humanoid. I have humanoids on my screen any time you look,” Tedrake says. “We’re going to try to smash the control problem for that.” Connoisseur of chaos - MIT News Office Where other roboticists try to suppress the complex dynamics of mechanical systems, Russ Tedrake exploits them, to make control more efficient and versatile.

We are very excited about this study,” says Institute Professor Robert Langer. “It brings us one step closer to someday creating a tissue-engineered heart, and it shows how novel nanomaterials can play a role in this field.” Merging tissue and electronics - MIT News Office

A multi-institution team led by MIT researchers has identified a galaxy cluster seven billion light-years away that dwarfs most known clusters, churning out a dazzling 740 new stars per year in the central galaxy. Most massive and luminous galaxy cluster identified - MIT News Office Detection may confirm long-held theory.

“Higher temperatures lead to substantially lower economic growth in poor countries,” says Ben Olken, a professor of economics at MIT, who helped conduct the research. And while it’s relatively straightforward to see how droughts and hot weather might hurt agriculture, the study indicates that hot spells have much wider economic effects. The economic cost of increased temperatures - MIT News Office Study: Warming episodes hurt poor countries and limit long-term growth.

In some isolated clinics in parts of Africa, the electricity needed to power lights and medical devices is generated by expensive imported diesel fuel; the water supply can be so cold in winter that health workers can’t even wash their hands properly. But a startup company established by a team of MIT students and alumni aims to change that. Bringing power to the people — and heat as well - MIT News Office Sun-powered system developed by MIT students could provide electricity, heat and cooling to rural schools and clinics.

Researchers in MIT's Department of Biological Engineering will receive up to $32 million over the next five years to develop a technology platform that will mimic human physiological systems in the laboratory, using an array of integrated, interchangeable engineered human tissue constructs. DARPA and NIH to fund ‘human body on a chip’ research - MIT News Office MIT-led team to receive up to $32 million from DARPA and NIH to develop technology that could accelerate pace and efficiency of pharmaceutical testing.

An array of tiny ball bearings in a box “tends to give a hexagonal symmetry, even though it’s in a square box,” says Professor Caroline Ross. “But that’s not what circuit designers want. They want patterns with 90-degree angles” Research update: Chips with self-assembling rectangles - MIT News Office New technique allows production of complex microchip structures in one self-assembling step.

“The ability to ensure that the bottom of the boat doesn’t have a mine attached to it is really critical to vessel security today," MIT's Franz Hover Autonomous robot maps ship hulls for mines - MIT News Office Algorithms enable robot to navigate and view propellers and other complex structures.

“Holography works, it’s beautiful, nothing can touch its quality,” says Douglas Lanman, a postdoc at the MIT Media Lab. “The problem, of course, is that holograms don’t move. To make them move, you need to create a hologram in real time, and to do that, you need … little tiny pixels, smaller than anything we can build at large volume at low cost. So the question is, what do we have now? We have LCDs. They’re incredibly mature, and they’re cheap.” Glasses-free 3-D TV looks nearer - MIT News Office A new method for producing multiple-perspective 3-D images could prove more practical in the short term than holography.

Making the invisible visible: New software amplifies changes in video that are too subtle for the naked eye. http://web.mit.edu/newsoffice/2012/amplifying-invisible-video-0622.html Researchers amplify variations in video, making the invisible visible - MIT News Office New software amplifies changes in successive frames of video that are too subtle for the naked eye.

“Sometimes it’s important to come up with an alarm immediately, even if you are not yet positive exactly what it is happening,” says Christopher Amato. “If something bad is going on, you want to know about it as soon as possible.”  System improves automated monitoring of security cameras - MIT News Office New approach uses mathematics to reach a compromise between accuracy, speed.

“In the wild, you do see things change suddenly, and this model is a reasonable explanation, but it’s very hard to prove that this is happening,” Jeff Gore says. “This is the kind of thing we can do in the laboratory that you can’t do in the wild.” From yeast, researchers learn how populations collapse - MIT News Office Findings could help fishery and wildlife managers monitor their stocks before disaster strikes.

“We are witnessing an unprecedented period of growth in unstructured digital data on the Web and in the cloud. And this will only further accelerate through the rapid growth of mobile devices such as smartphones and connected cars,” said Intel’s CTO, Justin Rattner. MIT, Intel unveil new initiatives addressing ‘big data’ - MIT News Office An Intel research center based at MIT will be the cornerstone of a new research project dubbed ‘bigdata@CSAIL.’

Getting a shot at the doctor’s office may become less painful in the not-too-distant future. Device may inject a variety of drugs without using needles - MIT News Office Jet-injected drugs could improve patient compliance, reduce accidental needle sticks.

“We don’t know how proteins that reside in the nuclear membrane actually get there. We don’t understand how viruses interact with the pore and how they go through. And we don’t understand how such an enormous spectrum of substrates can go through the same pore,” Thomas Schwartz says.  Piece by piece - MIT News Office MIT biologist Schwartz relishes the challenge of picking apart the cell’s most complex structure.

"Suppose that I'm a node in a network, and I see a communication coming in, and it is corrupted by noise," says Muriel Médard, a professor of electrical engineering and computer science. "I could try to remove the noise, but by doing that, I'm in effect making a decision right now that maybe would have been better taken by someone downstream from me who might have had more observations of the same source." The elusive capacity of networks - MIT News Office Calculating the total capacity of a data network is a notoriously difficult problem, but information theorists are beginning to make some headway.
ROBOTS! Whirr, click, hum: Robots go at it in 2.007 finale - MIT News Office Competition concludes mechanical design class, unleashing a wide variety of spinning, pumping and striking robots.

“It’s been absolutely fascinating to be a freshman advisor,” says President Susan Hockfield. “I learned a lot about the freshman experience. “If we can create equipment that will help grocery stores manage things more precisely, and maybe lower their losses by 30 percent, that would be huge,” says Swager, the John D. MacArthur Professor of Chemistry. Comparing apples and oranges - MIT News Office New sensor can accurately measure fruits’ ripeness, helping prevent loss of produce from spoilage.

Mucus often elicits strong revulsion, but to MIT biological engineer Katharina Ribbeck, it is a fascinating material: “Without it, we wouldn’t be able to smell, we wouldn’t be able to reproduce, and we would all be the victims of pathogens." Immune protection from an unexpected source - MIT News Office MIT biological engineers find that proteins in mucus help ward off viral infection.

Ultimately, the researchers hope it can be made using an inexpensive manufacturing process that could be applied to optical devices, the screens of smartphones and televisions, solar panels, car windshields and even windows in buildings. Through a glass, clearly - MIT News Office MIT researchers find a way to make glass that’s anti-fogging, self-cleaning and free of glare.

“We wanted to help inspire young people to change the world through engineering and science, and realized that the 10,000 superstar students we have at MIT are uniquely positioned to do that,” says Ian A. Waitz, dean of the School of Engineering and the Jerome C. In robotics, “today’s technology is going to look so incredibly primitive in a couple of decades,” Brooks said. The robot revolution is just beginning - MIT News Office Rodney Brooks outlines his vision of the future to student entrepreneurs.

Nancy Leveson, professor of aeronautics and astronautics and engineering systems at MIT, says increasing complexity is also making systems more vulnerable to accidents.  Engineering a safer world - MIT News Office Workshop explores safety in nuclear power plants, occupational health, aviation and medicine.

You have to give Donald Sadoway points for style: Not many professors come to the last class of a semester dressed in black tie, decorate the table with linen and a vase of fresh roses, and toast their students with champagne. But then, Sadoway has a tendency to do things differently. Taking an innovative approach to battery design - MIT News Office Donald Sadoway’s radical rethinking of electricity storage could revitalize renewable-power technologies.

Congratulations to Professor Nancy Lynch, named today as the 2012-2013 Athena Lecturer by the ACM-W Lynch named Athena Lecturer by ACM - MIT News Office Professor honored for advances in distributed systems that enable dependable Internet and wireless network applications.

“The microelectronics industry has changed computation, communications and consumer electronics in a big way,” says Charles Sodini, the Clarence J. LeBel Professor of Electrical Engineering at MIT and a co-founder of the MEDRC. “The medical device industry looks like one the microelectronics industry could affect as well.”  Their own devices - MIT News Office MIT’s Medical Electronic Device Realization Center forges a path connecting microelectronics and new health-care tools.

The latest installment in our "Future of Manufacturing" series. Moving microfluidics from the lab bench to the factory floor - MIT News Office The Center for Polymer Microfabrication designs manufacturing processes for a new generation of diagnostic tools.

“I think this concept could become an important part of the future of photovoltaics,” says the paper’s senior author, Jeffrey Grossman, the Carl Richard Soderberg Career Development Associate Professor of Power Engineering at MIT. A new dimension for solar energy - MIT News Office Innovative 3-D designs from an MIT team can more than double the solar power generated from a given area.

Sometimes the fastest pathway from point A to point B is not a straight line: for example, if you’re underwater and contending with strong and shifting currents. But figuring out the best route in such settings is a monumentally complex problem — especially if you’re trying to do it not just for one underwater vehicle, but for a swarm of them moving all at once toward separate destinations. Sometimes the quickest path is not a straight line - MIT News Office New methods and software developed at MIT can predict optimal paths for automated underwater vehicles.
Our latest student profile: Jacob Wamala The helper - MIT News Office Senior puts engineering skills, desire to serve toward improving the lives of disadvantaged and marginalized populations.

A new study co-authored by MIT economist David Autor shows that the rapid rise in low-wage manufacturing industries overseas has indeed had a significant impact on the United States. The disappearance of U.S. manufacturing jobs frequently leaves former manufacturing workers unemployed for years, if not permanently, while creating a drag on local economies and raising the amount of taxpayer-borne social insurance necessary to keep workers and their families afloat.  When (and where) work disappears - MIT News Office Study: Overseas manufacturing competition hits U.S. regions hard, leaving workers unemployed for years and local economies struggling.

“If you want to create a system with 50 circuits that are all working together as part of a computation that the cell is running, then you need each one of those individual circuits to not interfere with all the others. Toying with biological systems - MIT News Office By swapping microbial genes, Chris Voigt designs cells with novel functions.

“For every one of these 36 flavors, someone hated it and someone liked it. “When you go skiing off the path, you don’t ski in a way that you can always stop before the first tree you see,” Frazzoli says. “You ski and you see an opening, and then you trust that once you go there, you’ll be able to see another opening and keep going.” Speed limit for birds - MIT News Office MIT researchers find critical speed above which birds — and drones — are sure to crash.

A team of researchers, including an MIT postdoc, has found a dark dwarf galaxy about 10 billion light years from Earth. It is only the second such galaxy ever observed outside our local region of the universe, and is by far the most distant. Astronomers find a dark matter galaxy far, far away - MIT News Office Discovery could offer clues on the nature of dark matter.

Eran Egozy ’95, an MIT electrical engineering and computer science major and a concert-level clarinetist, met music major Alex Rigopulos ’92, ’94 when both were grad students at MIT’s Media Lab. They went on to establish Harmonix Music Systems, which in 2005 released the video game Guitar Hero.  MIT School of Humanities, Arts, & Social Sciences “You actually feel like a rock god." 
— Eran Egozy '95

Story in MIT Spectrvm magazine: http://bit.ly/18sfKSp
The MIT Listening Room: http://bit.ly/Tl5MaH

Egozy, along with Alex Rigopulos '92 '94, co-founded Harmonix and produced two of the finest music video games of the decade, Guitar Hero and Rock Band. (Photocredit: Len Rubenstein)
